conbody.p: String functions perform operations on a string input value and returns a string or other value.

section.title: CONTAINS(expression, substring)
section.p: True if the string contains the substring.

section.title: INITCAP(expression), TITLE(expression)
section.p: Converts the string so that the first letter of each word is uppercase and every other letter is lowercase.

section.title: LENGTH(expression)
section.p: Returns length of the string value.

section.title: LOWER(expression)
section.p: Returns lowercase of the string value.

section.title: LTRIM(expression [, characters ])
section.p: Returns string with all leading characters removed. White space is trimmed by default. The function removes leading characters from the expression that match the specified characters and stops when it encounters a character that does not match any of the specified characters.

section.title: POSITION(expression, substring)
section.p: Returns the first position of the substring within the string, or -1. The position is zero-based, i.e., the first position is 0.

section.title: REPEAT(expression, n)
section.p: Returns string formed by repeating expression n times.

section.title: REPLACE(expression, substring, repl [, n ])
section.p: Returns string with all occurrences of substr replaced with repl. If n is given, at most n replacements are performed.

section.title: REVERSE(expression)
section.p: This function reverses a given string.

section.title: RTRIM(expression, [, characters ])
SPLIT(expression [, sep ])
section.p: Splits the string into an array of substrings separated by the specified separator sep. If sep is not given, any combination of white space characters is used.

section.title: SUBSTR(expression, position [, length ])
section.p: Returns substring from the integer position of the given length, or to the end of the string. The position is zero-based, i.e. the first position is 0. If position is negative, it is counted from the end of the string; -1 is the last position in the string.

section.title: SUFFIXES(expression)
section.p: Generates an array of all the suffixes of the input string.

section.p: Converts the string so that the first letter of each word is uppercase and every other letter is lowercase.

section.title: TOKENS()
section.p: This function tokenizes the given input string based on specified delimiters, and other options. It recursively enumerates all tokens in a JSON value and returns an array of values (JSON atomic values) as the result.
The important thing to note is that first expression passed into token can be anything: constant literal, simple JSON value, JSON key name or the whole document itself.

The following table lists the rules for each JSON type:
JSON Type Return Value
MISSING []
NULL [NULL]
false [false]
true [true]
number [number]
string SPLIT(string)
array FLATTEN(TOKENS(element) for each element in array
(Concatenation of element tokens)
object For each name-value pair, name+TOKENS(value)
In the following example, TOKENS() converts all of the URL data into UPPER case and also adds the full URL to the delimited words.
section.codeblock: SELECT TOKENS(url) AS defaulttoken, TOKENS(url, {"specials":true, "case":"UPPER"}) AS specialtoken FROM `travel-sample` h WHERE h.type = 'hotel' LIMIT 1; [ { "defaulttoken": [ "uk", "www", "http", "yha", "org" ], "specialtoken": [ "ORG", "WWW", "HTTP://WWW.YHA.ORG.UK", "YHA", "UK", "HTTP" ] } ]
section.p: You can also use {"case":"lower"} or {"case":"upper"} to have case insensitive search. Index creation and querying can use this and other parameters in combination. These parameters should be passed within the query predicates as well. The parameters and values have to match exactly for N1QL to pick up and use the index correctly. The following example shows how you can create an index and use it your application.
section.codeblock: CREATE INDEX idx_url_upper_special on `travel-sample`( DISTINCT ARRAY v for v in tokens(url, {"specials":true, "case":"UPPER"}) END ) where type = 'hotel' ;

section.title: TRIM(expression [, characters ])
section.p: Returns string with all leading and trailing chars removed. White space by default.

section.title: UPPER(expression)
section.p: Returns uppercase of the string value.
The following example shows the use of a LOWER string function.
section.codeblock: SELECT product FROM product UNNEST product.categories as categories WHERE LOWER(categories) = "appliances"
